div.head: Catharine Maria Sedgwick to Theodore Sedgwick I
div.p: I received my dear Papa your letter by Te Theodore II but unfortunately was out when he called; since then your letter by the Mail has arrived -- The last gave me more pleasure than anything else probably could, for it assured me of Mama’s returning health -- since her last illness, I have felt more anxious than ever to be with yo her -- While you my dear Father are; I am confident she wants nothing -- every comfort, and every gratification, is administered to her from the right source --. I think her indisposition must have proceded from a cold, for the sharp air of in the hall, has always evidently affected her.

You say dear Papa you have been to Albany,
that you found our dear Eliza composed and cheerful -- surely her fortitude is wonderful; her resignation -- is something more than human, -- -- something heavenly – Pamela was a most lovely child. I am sensible her anguish at the moment must have exceeded every thing-- We have surely a great example before us in our invaluable Parents, Eliza has profited by it -- that we all may is my most constant prayer. -- -- I am pleased to hear that Mrs Bell remembers me with affection. I think I shall rarely meet with a woman who so exactly suits my taste as she does, & who is entitled from her exalted mind, manners, and morals, to respect, admiration, & love from all who know her -- Nothing (I think) could be of more service to, & certainly nothing more gratify me than to be in a situation where I could again
receive instruction from her. I shall my dear Papa always aim (at least) to do as you wish me, with respect to consulting the ladies you mention; and always “implicitly” follow their advice -- -- -- Mrs Jay I have not yet seen, which by the by I have a little wondered at -- Mr & Mrs Q have both been very attentive & kind to me. Mrs T you know always is --Your little favorite Mrs W Sullivan has been particularly attentive to me -- -- -- -- You inquire of me how my French progresses upon this I can answer you with a good conscience. I hardly find time to attend to any thing else. I am very fond of it & it is my opinion that I come on very well -- -- My best love to Mama -- & all my friends near & dear.
div.closer: Believe me my dear Father your affectionate childCMS

note.p: Collection. Sedgwick Family Papers, TSIA Box 2, Folder 23
“1804” is a later correction or clarification of the date.
CMS appears to have written 1803, but this date is belied by the death date of Pamela Dwight Pomeroy; see below.
Pamela Dwight Pomeroy, b. February 22, 1803; d. November 30, 1804. Fourth child of Eliza Sedgwick Pomeroy and Thaddeus Pomeroy.
CMS attended Mrs. Bell’s school in Albany in 1803.
